# Read in the Data

```{r, eval=FALSE}
## Data is in .sav form (SPSS)
library(haven)
d <- read_spss("Data/Ihno_dataset.sav")
```

```{r, echo=FALSE}
library(haven)
d <- read_spss("~/Dropbox/Teaching/EDUC 6600/Data/Ihno_dataset.sav")
```

--
### And Clean It

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
## install.packages("tidyverse")
library(tidyverse)
d_clean <- d %>%
  mutate(Major = factor(Major, labels = c("Psychology", "Premed",
                                          "Biology", "Sociology",
                                          "Economics"))) %>%
  mutate(Coffee = factor(Coffee))
```

---
# Frequency Tables Review

.pull-left[
```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(furniture)
tableF(d_clean, Major)
```
]

.pull-right[
```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
tableF(d_clean, Phobia)
```
]

---
# Frequency Viz's

.Huge[For viz's, we will use `ggplot2`]

<br>

.huge[This provides the most powerful, beautiful framework for data visualizations]

--

.large[.large[
- It is built on making .dcoral[layers]
- Each plot has a .nicegreen["geom"] function
    - e.g. `geom_bar()` for bar charts, `geom_histogram()` for histograms, etc.
]]


---
# Bar Charts

```{r, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}
ggplot(d_clean, aes(x = Major)) +
  geom_bar()
```

---
# Bar Charts

```{r, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}
ggplot(d_clean, aes(x = Coffee)) +
  geom_bar()
```

---
# Histograms

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}
ggplot(d_clean, aes(x = Phobia)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 1)
```

---
# Histograms (change bins to size 3)

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}
ggplot(d_clean, aes(x = Phobia)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 3)
```

---
# Histograms (change bins to size 5)

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}
ggplot(d_clean, aes(x = Phobia)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 5)
```

---
# Histograms

```{r, message=FALSE, warning=FALSE, fig.width=8, fig.height=6}
ggplot(d_clean, aes(x = Mathquiz)) +
  geom_histogram(binwidth = 4)
```
